text: so we've all experienced the pain
frustration hassle at one point or
another of patchy or sometimes
non-existent network connectivity so
maybe you've been out for a drive in a
remote area of Australia got your phone
out taking a photograph of the beautiful
countryside that surrounds us gone to
share it with your friends on social
media and you can't because there isn't
any network connectivity and this is a
problem that will occur in 70% of
locations around of Australia the
problem is not unique to Australia and
it's also not unique to the internet for
humans it's actually blocking the
adoption of the Internet of Things and
bearing this connectivity issue in mind
we'll now take a look at the state of
the art for water tank monitoring on a
large farm so this is Tom taking a very
long drive to go and see how much water
is in the tank on his farm and he'll
drive around the farm to do that
throughout the tanks to get one very
small but very important piece of
information which is how much water is
in a tank because if the tanks empty
then the stock are hungry and on a farm
the applications like this that need a
very small amount of highly valuable
data are certainly not limited to tank
monitoring we're talking about other
applications like soil moisture probes
water flow meters weather stations all
the way through to tracking of
individual cattle themselves and then if
we look more broadly beyond agriculture
we can consider a whole suite of
industry verticals that have mobile and
remote operations and a need to get
small amounts of highly valuable data so
this includes industries like utilities
for gas electricity water metering like
logistics and asset tracking prevent
maintenance maritime for vessel tracking
and aids to navigation and then
monitoring our environment groundwater
levels and on the ocean and then a whole
suite of applications within defense as
well
and while these different verticals are
quite different in their nature they all
have one thing in common which is that
they have this need to get a small
amount of really valuable data back to a
location whether it's for tracking
sensing and so on the data might be
small but the benefits huge we're
talking about bringing this data
together the problems that can solve a
massive when we look at the bigger
picture here we're talking about
securing our food and water supply
securing our environment and securing
our people at mariota we deliver
Internet of Things connectivity
everywhere and we do this at an ultra
low cost with very long battery life in
a secure and private way and provide
global coverage and the way that we
provide that level of coverage is to use
satellites and when many people think
about satellites they think of large
heavy expensive spacecraft like the one
on the left here costing hundreds of
millions of dollars weighing a lot and
costing a lot of money to get out into
orbit in contrast we use much smaller
satellites like the one on the right
here that weigh about 5 kilos and can be
put on orbit built and put on orbit for
around a million dollars and we put them
into a lower orbit where they orbit the
Earth at roughly one time every hour and
a half
so if we take a look at our journey and
where we started
Mariota began in 2011 within the
Institute for telecommunications
research at the University of South
Australia with support from the
Australian Space Research Program and
what we did was we undertook a
premeditated commercialization we
identified a gap in the market the need
for this type of connectivity and then
we went out and we spoke to potential
customers of the service and those
conversations went along the lines of
how often would you need to get your
data what size of message how long would
the battery need to ask all of these
kind of requirements analysis questions
that happen before we started to do the
research we then set about identifying
and then solving the build deep tech
problems here so from a
telecommunications perspective there are
a number of these we developed the
algorithms and the architectures and the
solutions for them we demonstrated those
first in simulation and then we took
them up into aircraft trials to show
them working in the real world based on
the success of the aircraft trials we
then took them through to initial
satellite trials and we first validated
this system with real satellites back in
2013 so the technology we're talking
about here is very mature and we filed
patents protecting that technology that
far back as well
and won some awards along the way and
based on that in late 2015
we spun the company out and we did this
with the support of a Canadian company
satellite owner and operator exact earth
who provided the capital to get us
started and also provided us with access
to their Leo satellites
and then we said about taking those
prototypes and the demonstrated working
technology transferring that into
product building the product and putting
it into the hands of real customers for
their POCs
we took on some more investment we had
paid proof of concept field trials with
customers we mitigated and we D risked
all of the technical risks and
regulatory risks and at the same time
built our sales pipeline in March last
year we closed a Series A funding round
to grow the company to build our sales
pipeline further and to expand our
constellation that was a twenty million
dollar round led by Australian financial
investors and also brought with it
Boeing's horizon X with Boeing making
their first investment outside of the
United States and SingTel innovate and
then earlier this year we appointed Pam
Melroy
as an independent director to our board
Pam has a huge background in space
having piloted and commanded Space
Shuttle missions as well as having held
senior roles within defense and the and
the US government she's incredibly smart
connected and respected and on top of
that a great person to work with so we
have a very strong board and now we'll
move on to talking about our system
so devices in the field communicate
directly to our satellites and this is a
key feature of our system they don't
have to go by our ground-based piece of
infrastructure first which then talks to
satellites the devices can be deployed
everywhere and communicate directly to
orbit and our system and our algorithms
have been designed to support billions
of devices globally the satellites
capture these signals and then they
downlink them by our ground station
networks through to the cloud we then
deliver the messages through to the end
customer so just putting some numbers on
things here billions of devices devices
that can last in the field for more than
a decade using batteries that you can
purchase from your local supermarket and
a 10x cost reduction compared to the
existing services so in terms of price
point one sent to transmit a message
through the system
our module can be integrated into any
product to give it this capability so by
adding this module onto a PCB and a
small antenna the device can then
communicate directly by our satellite
network
this has edge processing capability it's
got an arm cortex-m forum on board it
also has all the standard types of
interfaces that you'll need to
communicate with IOT sensors it's been
designed for long battery life and it
also has our communication stack onboard
and it's accompanied by a very simple
but powerful software development kit
and API the devices then communicate to
our constellation of satellites in low
Earth orbit and you can see here our
current constellation with three
satellites that are in polar orbit so
they're passing over the poles providing
global coverage and then complementing
that with a satellite that's in
equatorial orbit these satellites
provide global coverage but doing this
also comes with a number of challenges
so to start with we're talking about
devices where we're aiming to maximize
battery life so that means our
transmitters are effectively whispering
and combining that with the fact that
they're not talking to a base station
that might be kilometres away but
they're actually communicating with a
spacecraft that could be two and a half
thousand kilometres away when it's out
on the horizon and the closer that's
going to get to the device is 600 k's
away when it's directly above it's
hurtling through the sky at seven and a
half kilometers per second so all of
these things do quite some interesting
stuff to the radio channel
and to make matters worse we're not just
having one device communicate with the
satellite but if you look at the size of
this footprint here that represents the
surface of the earth that the satellite
receiver can see and so that means that
when the satellite is above Alice
Springs it can see the entire country of
Australia so you have devices in Broome
in Perth Townsville Hobart all
simultaneously communicating with the
spacecraft so that's a massive
multi-user access problem
and we've innovated in a way that
enables that massive scale access a very
long battery life by doing very clever
signal processing and very clever
scheduling very clever waveform design
and then using system architectures that
enable all of these features for our end
customers and adding enter in security
and privacy on top of that as well and
so there's some really deep tech
innovation here that covers everything
from the algorithms and the
architectures through the applications
and that we've filed across 21 patterns
so what we're talking about here is a
unique capability and differentiating
technology and then if we think about
now how do we join forces with AWS and
how do we use AWS to take our solution
out to market well it's really about
adding our unique capability and ID tag
onto the undifferentiated heavy lifting
the idea AWS gives us and we use AWS as
cloud computing storage we use managed
services and recently the AWS ground
station so let's take a bit of a look at
what I mean by that our satellites
capture the signals as raw spectrum
they have an RF front-end and they do an
analog-to-digital conversion and they
take what they are hearing through two
digital samples and at that point they
stop and they store that and it's a
store and forward system that then takes
the outcome of that and then down links
that spectrum by the ground station
network into s3 so we're doing a
director orbit capture overall spectrum
with a store and forward through the s3
and then what happens next is we invoke
an event-driven data pipeline the first
step in this is the implementation of
our software-defined radio so this is
where we do the advanced multi-user
reception where we unjam ball that mess
of all of these simultaneous
transmissions and we effectively turn
raw spectrum take that and push out user
messages out of this side we do this by
running our SDR using batch on ec2 and
using spot fleet
and from there we have a series of
loosely coupled event-driven services we
move into event-driven lambdas for
authentication we track the message
messages through billing perform our
billing and then we feed the messages
via a message broker through to our
customers via a restful api so what this
means for Mariota in terms of the
advantages it brings it gives us this
ability to add our unique IP on top of
this undifferentiated heavy lifting in a
way that enables a really rapid
transition from our ideas through to
value that we can deliver to our
customers a key feature here is that we
have a massively scalable communication
system but in terms of the
implementation here with the elastic
scalability that AWS provides that means
we don't have to consider the capacity
of that implementation upfront so we can
just hit hit the ground running and get
going and then seeing the way AWS ground
station as well follows the same
philosophy of providing this on-demand
access that's API driven we can combine
all of these things to deliver a very
scalable and cost-effective solution
so taking another look at the verticals
that we were talking about the form will
have a look at what some of our
customers are doing with our products
and service in order to support their
customers so this is a proof of concept
that we ran a while ago to put a tank
monitor in the hands of farmers and see
how they received it and the benefits
that they drew from it and you can see
here that we had these tank monitors
scattered around Australia very easy to
deploy pressure sensor into a tank with
a device that then transmitted the data
back through our network and ultimately
to through through to the farmer on
their phone and this say farmers
hundreds of kilometres driving and on
top of that it also provided timely
information back to them so it wasn't
once every few weeks the next time they
go for a drive to have a look at the
tanks it was multiple times a day they
could see how their tank was going and
at one point one of the farmers actually
gave us a call because they'd noticed
that their user interface had gone from
blue to orange to let them know that
that the tank was near empty and they a
bit skeptical about this because they
had seen it recently and thought there's
no way that tanks empty so they drove
out and took a look at it expecting this
to be a software bug but they actually
found that the tank was empty the the
pump had failed and they needed to fix
it so what was originally going to be a
call just to let us know about a problem
with the software actually became a call
to say thank you because it would have
been weeks before that farmer had gone
back out and seeing that the tank was
empty and that was a warm time of the
year and the stock would have been under
stress throughout their period and so
for us at mariota when we when we get
that kind of feedback from customers
that's massive because that that really
hammers home the end value that we're
providing to our customers and into
users with the real-world applications
that where it actually makes a
difference here since that POC a number
of OMS have taken our connectivity and
added to their products to support
agriculture like Devi water products
with their tank sense monitor like MEA
who have a suite of green brain products
for a microclimate station a tank
monitor and also for soil moisture
probes and they feed the data that comes
from that into their front end so that
they can give farmers insight into soil
moisture in their Shiraz bean yard or
weather information around the farm and
all of this is enabled by being able to
get that small high-value data from
everywhere
and then moving beyond AG we look to a
number of companies that are developing
products for preventative maintenance
like ping ping have an advanced acoustic
sensing that's able to detect issues
with wind turbines and they use me Ryota
connectivity to get the outcomes of that
back to the end-user that way and when
turbines can be repaired before it
becomes catastrophic we've been working
with the Australian Institute of Marine
Science since before we spun the company
out they use our connectivity for their
oceanographic drifters where that
provides them with information on the
currents the temperature the humidity
and the pressure out on the oceans and
similarly we've been working with the
defence Science Technology Group for a
long time as well and a recent program
with them the fight recorder records the
motion of the warfighter
for event reconstruction and also
provides a personal beacon for alarms
again all of these applications are
enabled by Mariota providing that
connectivity for small amounts of really
valuable data that will do everything
from protect a wind turbine protect the
health of cattle through to protecting
the warfighter
and if we now take a look at beyond the
module itself we have a developer
toolkit which has this module mounted on
it on a developer board along with the
GPS and antennas battery holder and then
an easy-to-use interface through two
sensors everything you need to get up
and running in a lab accompanying that
is a satellites you later
so this gives our customers the ability
to run the system end-to-end in the lab
have the satellite simulator push the
captures through to our network and then
have our restful api then push the
messages back to the end customer so
everything in the lab then also as part
of the kit is an enclosure so once the
application is tested in the lab it can
be taken outside to run the initial POCs
before going to a larger scale part of
this is our software development kit and
our API that is really simple and really
powerful and gives everyone everything
they need to bring an application up
really quickly it has tracker examples
examples how to use the the resources
onboard the arm cortex-m for and makes
that edge processing and analysis that
you might want to do on that processor
of things like checking against
thresholds of a sensor reading these
kind of things before you package up
your message for transmission it makes
all of that very simple and then for
systems integrators who want to hit the
ground running and go to their
deployments quickly without having to
build their own enclosure we also have
the sense and locate device
which has a rugged ip67 enclosure
it has a very easy-to-use Universal
mounting plate everything that we
learned from our POCs initially with
customers we fed back into the design of
this to make sure that it's really easy
to use for the end-user it also has a 4
to 20 mili-amp
sensor interface with a gland at the
base there for routing that through to
make it very easy to integrate sensors
and it has onboard GNSS as well so
moving forward we're growing our sales
team we're expanding our market
footprint we're building three more
satellites which will be launched from
the end of this year and we're working
towards a larger constellation with the
next step shown here being 30 spacecraft
on-orbit having the additional
spacecraft reduces the gap in time
between opportunities for the devices to
communicate with the satellites and once
we get to 30 we're looking at a maximum
gap thereof in the order of 5 to 10
minutes and then ultimately pushing out
to 50 satellites in the constellation
for near real-time coverage and so by
combining mariota's unique IP to enable
this with what AWS provides in terms of
really scalable and cost-effective
undifferentiated heavy lifting we're
able to deliver IOT to our customers
everywhere thanks
[Applause]
